thread.title: DCB Bank alters expansion plans after stock takes a hit
thread.title_full: DCB Bank alters expansion plans after stock takes a hit

title: DCB Bank alters expansion plans after stock takes a hit
text:
Explore the comfort with green & gracious living at L&T Realty's EMERALD ISLE, Powai DCB Bank alters expansion plans after stock takes a hit After the revised expansion strategy, the markets gave a thumbs up to the stock which ended 3.75% up Private sector lender DCB (formerly Development Co-operative Bank) has now decided to double its branches in the next two years instead of the ambition plan of one year that it had earlier set out. This change in plan comes on the back of the beating that the stock took in the last two days. 
Private sector lender DCB (formerly Development Co-operative Bank) has now decided to double its branches in the next two years instead of the ambition plan of one year that it had earlier set out. This change in plan comes on the back of the beating that the stock took in the last two days. 
Over Tuesday and Wednesday the stock had tanked close to 31%. "The management has decided to install 150+ branches in a cautious, prudent ad calibrated manner over a period of 24 months (instead of 12 months," said DCB bank in a filing to the Bombay Stock Exchange. It also said that it has redrawn the plan after taking feedback from the investors, analysts and other stakeholders. At present, DCB has 160 branches ALSO READ: DCB Bank: Fast expansion plan to hit profitability After the revised expansion strategy, the markets gave a thumbs up to the stock which ended up 3.75% and closed at Rs 95.80. 
The branch expansion has been prompted by the rising competition with the coming of the new banks. "Competition is going to increase dramatically in the next one year on account of new payments banks, small finance banks being set up and also on account of existing banks increasing their expansion. So we need to be prepared for it," Murali Natrajan, Managing Director & CEO, DCB had told Business Standard earlier. ALSO READ: DCB Bank tanks over 30% in two days on downgrade by brokerages 
The aggressive expansion plans would have had let to higher expenditure by the lender and this in turn would have put pressure on the bank's margins, leading several brokerage houses to cut their earnings estimates. 
For the July-September quarter of this financial year the bank reported its net profit at Rs 37 crore against Rs 41 crore in the same period last year. The net profit was down on account of high provisioning and a steeper tax outgo. Latest News
